title: Martin Westgate
contents:
Bio




Martin leads the Science & Decision Support Team at the ALA, and is an honorary lecturer at the Fenner School of Environment & Society, ANU. His work focuses on conceptual, computational and statistical tools to better understand patterns in nature.



























Posts

Sunburst plots for taxonomic dataSince version 1.3.1 of galah, it has been possible to download taxonomic data using a ‘tree’ format from the data.tree package. Here I’ll demonstrate some ideas for plotting these trees using circular diagrams.Creating a color palette from an imageThere are hundreds of color palettes in the R ecosystem, but sometimes we might want to use colors from a specific image. Here I show how to use the paletter package to create a color palette for the 2020 Eucalypt of the Year

title: Dax Kellie
contents:
Bio




Dax is an evolutionary biologist, with a PhD in biological sciences and social psychology. As a data analyst at the ALA, he makes visualisations of what data are held in the ALA and tries to make these data accessible for scientists and citizen scientists to use. He also facilitates scientific rigour and transparency in the ALA’s workflow, and works to make it easier for researchers to do the same.



























Posts

title: Matilda Stevenson
contents:
Posts

Hex maps for species occurrence dataHex maps are a neat way to represent spatial information. Here, we show how to draw one using the most common species in the ALA database

title: Shandiya Balasubramaniam
contents:
Bio




Shandiya is an evolutionary ecologist with interests in conservation genetics and wildlife disease. Her work as a data analyst at the ALA focuses on streamlining reproducible pathways for researchers to access and analyse open data.



























Posts

title: Amanda Buyan
contents:
Bio




Amanda is a Data Analyst for EcoCommons, and is based at the Atlas of Living Australia. She completed her PhD in Structural Biology, and uses her extensive Python skills to manage the integration of data within EcoCommons. She also works to optimize the available scientific workflows within the platform.













Posts

title: Jessica Fenker
contents:
Bio




Jess is an evolutionary scientist based at Atlas of Living Australia, with a postdoc on species delimitation methods and PhD on diversification at micro/macro scales. She is also affiliated with the Division of Ecology and Evolution, ANU. Jess brings her experience in R to improve the readability, data standardisation and performance of EcoCommons’ platform ecological modelling algorithms. Jess is a strong advocate for diversity in STEMM.

title: Olivia Torresan
contents:
Bio




Olivia is a graduate from the Australian National University (ANU), acquiring an interdisciplinary double degree in philosophy and natural resource management. At the ALA, she works as a support officer with a primary focus on monitoring the research impact of the Atlas. She is passionate about accessibility, environmental justice and diversity in STEMM.













Posts

title: Jenna Wraith
contents:
Bio




Jenna is a conservation scientist with a PhD in Plant Ecology. She is currently the business and scientific analyst for EcoCommons Australia. Her role is to bring cutting-edge and best practice science and data to the EcoCommons platform. Jenna is a strong advocate for diversity and inclusion in STEMM fields.
